column1: # This file will be automatically parsed. It must contain the following four elements:
# These elements must be provided in the order shown with their respective headers.
# Any line that begins with a # is considered a comment and will be ignored when parsing.
# It is mandatory to submit logP predictions for all 11 molecules. Incomplete submissions will not be accepted.
# Please report logP standard error of the mean (SEM) and logP model uncertainty.
# The data in each prediction line should be structured as follows:
# The list of predictions must begin with the 'Predictions:' keyword as illustrated here.
# Please provide an informal but informative name of the method used.
# The 'Name:' keyword is required as shown here.
# List all major software packages used and their versions.
# Create a new line for each software.
# State which method category your prediction method is better described as:
# Level of details should be roughly equivalent to that used in a publication.
# Please include the values of key parameters with units. Please explain how statistical uncertainties were estimated.
# Use as many lines and paragraphs of text as you need.
# All text following the 'Method:' keyword will be regarded as part of your free text methods description.
logP values of 11 SAMPL6 molecules in the octanol/water partitioning system were established by extended solvent-contact model.
A potential energy function defined for each solvent with respect to atomic distributions and three kinds of atomic parameters.
Using the training set consisting of 49 organic molecules with varying shapes and functional groups
column2: atomic parameters were optimized by standard genetic algorithm for each solvent
solvation free energies of 11 SAMPL6 molecules could be obtained with respect to octanol/water
column3: and logP values were determined from the difference between the solvation free energy of a molecule in water and that in octanol.
